author: Rachel Halliwell
title: Embarrassing driving stories: arguing while driving
text: >> More extraordinary road tales It’s hard not to remember the day you got married with great clarity – after all, it’s you committing and declaring your love to the person you want to grow old with in front of the people who mean most to you. But for me, the final moments I spent with my intended on the eve of our wedding are also etched oh-so clearly on my memory. Is that because of some sweet and impossibly romantic gesture on his part? Or a tender moment we shared, which has our three children swooning when I regale the story? I’m afraid not. In actual fact, Carl and I had a blazing row – goodness knows what it was about this time – that meant the only passion that was stirred, in me at least, was absolute fury. I then stormed off to my mother’s in my clapped out Mini Metro, with my fiancé in hot pursuit This bust-up (if only I could remember the details, but it was 23 years ago this summer) ended with me, in a fit of pique, calling him something unmentionably rude and unpublishable before announcing that he’d better not count on seeing me at church the next day. My spleen fully vented, I then stormed off to my mother’s in my clapped out Mini Metro… with my fiancé in hot pursuit. Carl caught up with me at a set of traffic lights, where he beeped his horn and signalled for me to pull over. Of course, I ignored him. At the second set of lights, he was able to pull up alongside me, where he wound down his window and bellowed through it that I was a “pain in the backside” but would I please pull over at the next layby. At the side of a busy dual carriageway, leaning against the first car I owned, Carl held me The site of my husband-to-be, clearly frantic that I might actually have meant it all and that he was facing a jilting at the altar had the desired effect – my heart softened just enough to do as he pleaded. By the time I drove into that layby I actually felt sorry that once again my hot temper and his uncanny knack of winding me up had spoilt our final moments together before we became a married couple. Only it hadn’t. Because at the side of a busy dual carriageway, leaning against the first car I owned, Carl held me in his arms and we kissed and made up. I might have appeared slightly sulky at first, but in my heart that’s when I truly knew this was the man I wanted to spend the rest of my life with. And so, of course, I did turn up at church the following day where the next words we spoke to each other were “I do”. And funnily enough, that’s a story our kids love as much as we do. • Happy driving experiences lead to happy marriages.
